questions.text: 30 years old male presents with inflammatory low back pain for last 6 months. His one brother also has similar complain. Recently he presented with acute red eye of right eye. Evaluation shows RF and anti-CCP is negative and HLAB27 is positive. MRI shows sclerosis of both sacroiliac joint. There is no history of psoriasis in the patient or any of the blood relatives. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient there is no history of any psoriasis or inflammatory bowel disease. therefore he can't be classified as psoriatic arthritis or inflammatory bowel disease associated

  • Spondyloarthritis (SpA) refers to a group of overlapping disorders that share clinical features, genetic associations, and pathogenic mechanisms.
  • SpA includes ankylosing spondylitis (AS), reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis (PsA), arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), juvenile spondyloarthritis (JSpA), and undifferentiated SpA.
  • Primarily it affects the axial skeleton-the sacroiliac joint, vertebrae and its structures like facet joints. Axial structures also includes the hip and shoulder joint. Peripheral joints, like those seen in Rheumatoid arthritis, are also affected.

Features of Ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Laboratory features: No laboratory test is diagnostic of AS. HLA-B27 is present in 75-90% of patients. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are often, but not always, elevated. Mild anemia may be present. Patients with severe disease may show elevated alkaline phosphatase. Rheumatoid factor, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP), and antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) are largely absent.
  • Radiological- symmetrical erosion, sclerosis or pseudo-widening of sacroiliac joint, osteitis of anterior corners of vertebrae, squaring or even barreling of vertebrae, marginal syndesmophytes and in advanced stage bamboo spine.

Clinical tests for diagnosis-

  • Modified Schober test is used for measurement of lumbar spine flexion.
  • Chest expansion: Chest expansion is measured as the difference between maximal inspiration and maximal forced expiration at the levels of either the fourth intercostal space or the xiphisternum, with the patient's hands resting on or just behind the head. Normal chest expansion is ≥5 cm.
  • The factors most predictive of radiographic progression (see below) are the presence of existing syndesmophytes, high inflammatory markers, and smoking.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of axial spondyloarthritis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of Spondyloarthritis (SpA) listed in ASAS criteria for Spondyloarthritis must be memorized. So good response to NSAIDs is included in the criteria.

  • The most common extraarticular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis.
  • Enthesitis is inflammation of attachment points of muscle with bone.

questions.text: Flowing wax appearance on the anterior body of vertebrae is seen in which of the following clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Flowing wax pattern is seen in X-ray spine of Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis.

DISH

Ligamentous calcification gives the appearance of "flowing wax" on the anterior bodies of the vertebrae. Intervertebral disk spaces are preserved, and sacroiliac and facet joints appear normal, helping to differentiate DISH from ankylosing spondyloarthritis.

Psoriatic arthritis:

  • Enthesitis and marginal bone erosions; "pencil-in-cup" deformities are common, but not pathognomonic for PsA.
  • Periostitis: may appear as a periosteal layer of new bone, or as irregular thickening of the cortex itself
  • Dactylitis:which can present as a "sausage digit" which refers to soft tissue swelling of a whole digit; ultrasound examination of a sausage digit demonstrates underlying synovitis and tenosynovitis.
  • Acro-osteolysis
  • Arthritis mutilans: osteolysis and articular collapse can cause a phenomenon referred to as "telescoping fingers"
  • Ivory phalanx: classically involving the distal phalanx of the great toe
  • Sacroiliitis: often asymmetrical (vs symmetrical in Ankylosing spondylitis)

questions.text: Which of the following is first line therapy for management of ankylosing spondylitis?
questions.solution:
Therapy for Ankylosing spondylitis: NSAIDs are first line therapy unless contraindicated.

Once Trial of NSAIDs fail, any drug from second line can be chosen. However in the presence of inflammatory bowel disease TNF Inhibitors is preferred and in case of extensive psoriatic skin lesions anti IL-17 inhibitors are preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of classic triad of reactive arthritis?
questions.solution:
REACTIVE ARTHRITIS:

  • Acute arthritis 1-4 weeks after episode of diarrhea or urethritis.
  • Definite bacterial triggers of ReA include several Salmonella spp., Shigella spp., Yersinia enterocolitica, Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, Campylobacter jejuni, and Chlamydia trachomatis. These are all gram-negative bacteria containing lipopolysaccharide (LPS).
  • HLA-B27 Positive status predisposes individuals genetically.
  • Clinical Features:
  • Arthritis-asymmetrical, additive, large joint predominant
  • Dactylitis or sausage digits
  • Enthesitis
  • Ocular manifestations- conjunctivitis, acute anterior uveitis
  • Mucocutaneous lesions- oral ulcers, keratoderma blennorrhagica, (most common on the palms and soles), Lesions on the glans penis, termed circinate balanitis.

Diagnosis:

  • ReA is a clinical diagnosis with no definitively diagnostic laboratory test or radiologic finding.
  • Reactive arthritis shares many features with Psoriatic arthritis. However, PsA is usually gradual in onset; the arthritis tends to affect primarily the upper extremities; and there are usually no associated mouth ulcers, urethritis, or bowel symptoms.
  • Treatment- most of the cases resolve within 6 months. NSAIDs, Intraarticular corticosteroids are considered first line therapy. Sulfasalazine has been found to have benefit in people with persistent articular symptoms.

questions.text: Ray distribution of joint involvement is seen in which of the following arthritis?
questions.solution:
Psoriatic arthritis

  • It is classified under ankylosing spondyloarthritis
  • HLA B27, HLA-B57, B27, -B38, and -B39 are genetic risk factor for this.
  • In 70% of cases, psoriasis precedes joint disease. In 15% of cases, the two manifestations appear within 1 year of each other. In about 15% of cases, the arthritis precedes the onset of psoriasis.
  • Wright and mall had described five patterns of arthritis in psoriatic arthritis:
    1. arthritis of the DIP joints;
    2. asymmetric oligoarthritis;
    3. symmetric polyarthritis similar to RA;
    4. axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joints); and
    5. arthritis mutilans, a highly destructive form of the disease.
  • Nail changes (pitting, horizontal ridging, onycholysis, yellowish discoloration of the nail margins, dystrophic hyperkeratosis, and combinations of these findings) in the fingers or toes occur in most patients with PsA, compared with only a minority of psoriatic patients without arthritis, and pustular psoriasis is said to be associated with more severe arthritis.
  • Dactylitis and enthesitis are common in PsA and help to distinguish it from other joint disorders.
  • Joint involvement tends to follow a "ray" distribution, with all of the joints of one finger involved, while sparing adjacent fingers entirely.
  • Eye involvement, either conjunctivitis or uveitis, is reported in 7-33% of PsA
  • CASPER criteria (Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis) is the classification criteria for Psoriatic arthritis
  • Drug therapy for Psoriatic arthritis is similar to Ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Type 1 Autoimmune pancreatitis is a manifestation of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
• IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD) is a fibroinflammatory condition characterized by a tendency to form tumefactive lesions.
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis is a manifestation of IgG4 related disease:
  • Type 1 autoimmune pancreatitis, presents as mild abdominal pain; weight loss; acute, obstructive jaundice, mimicking adenocarcinoma of the pancreas (including a pancreatic mass);
  • Between 20 and 50% of patients present with acute glucose intolerance
  • imaging shows diffuse (termed "sausage-shaped pancreas") or segmental pancreatic enlargement, with loss of normal lobularity; a mass often raises the suspicion of malignancy.

Other important organ manifestations of IgG4 related disease:

Hallmark Histopathological features of IgG4 related disease:

  • Storiform Fibrosis
  • Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate.

questions.text: Which of the following is a hereditary autoinflammatory syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hereditary Autoinflammatory syndromes:

  • The autoinflammatory syndromes comprise a clinically distinct set of disorders unified by recurrent febrile episodes accompanied by inflammatory cutaneous, mucosal, serosal, and osteoarticular manifestations.
  • The innate immune system plays a predominant role in the pathogenesis of the autoinflammatory diseases.

The various autoinflammatory syndromes include:

  • Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF)
  • TNF receptor associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS)
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia D with periodic fever syndrome (HIDS), also known as mevalonate kinase deficiency
  • Muckle-Wells syndrome (MWS)
  • Neonatal-onset multisystem inflammatory disease(NOMID)

The pathogenic genes involved :

questions.text: Which of the following drug/drugs is associated with Tendon rupture?
Finkelstein test is used for diagnosis of which of the following musculoskeletal disease?
questions.solution: List of common clinical tests:

questions.text: Gout is caused by intraarticular Precipitation of which of the following Crystals?
questions.solution:
Hyperuricemia and gout are associated with multiple cardiovascular-metabolic comorbidities, including obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, myocardial infarction, stroke, and urate nephrolithiasis.

  • Occurs due to precipitation of monosodium urate crystals.
  • Most common presentation is recurrent attacks of Monoarthritis.
  • The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees.
  • Longstanding untreated disease can manifest as chronic gouty arthritis which is associated with ongoing synovitis, subcutaneous tophi, deformity, and bony destruction.
  • Presence of needle shaped strongly negatively Birefringrent monosodium urate crystals in the synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of Gouty arthritis.

Drugs for acute gouty arthritis:

Acute arthritis- NSAIDS, Colchicine, Intramuscular or oral glucocorticoids.

Urate lowering Therapy:

  • Xanthine oxidase Inhibitors-Allopurinol, Febuxostat
  • Uricosuric Drugs- probenecid, Benzbromarone
  • Uricase enzyme-Pegloticase

HLA-B*5801 allele is associated with allopurinol hypersensitivity syndrome.

Drugs that are known to reduce serum uric acid level:

  • Losartan
  • Amlodipine
  • Fenofibrate
  • Sodium glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitor

Calcium Pyrophosphate causes Pseudogout and is associated with chondrocalcinosis.

questions.text: All of the following are primary vasculitis syndrome except?
questions.solution:
• Vasculitis is a clinicopathologic process characterized by inflammation of and damage to blood vessels. The vessel lumen is usually compromised, and this is associated with ischemia of the tissues supplied by the involved vessel.
  • Vasculitis and its consequences may be the primary or sole manifestation of a disease (called as primary vasculitis syndrome) or vasculitis may be a secondary component of another disease (when it is called as secondary vasculitis syndrome)
  • Primary vasculitis is classified on the basis of the predominant size of vessels affected by the disease process: Chapel hill classification 20012
  • Please remember the names of ANCA associated vasculitis:
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Microscopic polyangiitis
  • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis

questions.text: Granuloma formation is seen in all of the following primary vasculitis syndromes except?
questions.solution:
Other mechanisms involved in pathogenesis of Primary vasculitis include:

  • Antibody mediated:
  • Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody mediated:
  • Cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA)-antibodies bind to indicator neutrophils. Proteinase-3, a 29-kDa neutral serine proteinase present in neutrophil azurophilic granules, is the major c-ANCA antigen. More than 90% of patients with active granulomatosis with polyangiitis have detectable antibodies to proteinase-3.
  • Perinuclear ANCA (p-ANCA)-The major target for p-ANCA is the enzyme myeloperoxidase; other targets that can produce a p-ANCA pattern of staining include elastase, cathepsin G, lactoferrin, lysozyme, and bactericidal/permeability-increasing protein. However, only antibodies to myeloperoxidase have been convincingly associated with vasculitis. Anti-Myeloperoxidase antibodies have been reported to occur in variable percentages of patients with microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg- Strauss), isolated necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • A p-ANCA (not due to anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies) seen in rheumatic and nonrheumatic autoimmune diseases, inflammatory bowel disease, certain drugs like Methimazole endocarditis bacterial airway infections in patients with cystic fibrosis.

Drugs that can cause vasculitis like syndrome:

Cocaine

Levamisole

Amphetamines

Ergot alkaloids

Methysergide Arsenic

questions.text: A 30 years old female presents with Headache and claudication of both upper limbs. On examination both radial and brachial pulses are absent, BP in right leg is 150/60 mmHg and Left leg is 110/60 mmHg. Carotid Bruit is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis is a large vessel predominant disease,

Polyarteritis Nodosa is medium vessel predominant disease and granulomatosis with polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis is a small vessel disease.

  • Loss of pulses, asymmetry of pulses indicates involvement of large vessel involvement.
  • Therefore most likely diagnosis is Takayasu Arteritis..

Takayasu arteritis:

  • An inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium- and large-sized arteries characterized by a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches.
  • The involvement of the major branches of the aorta is much more marked at their origin than distally.
  • The disease is a pan arteritis with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasionally giant cells.
  • Clinical And Laboratory Manifestations:
  • Generalized symptoms include malaise, fever, night sweats, arthralgias, anorexia, and weight loss, which may occur months before vessel involvement is apparent.
  • Pulses are commonly absent in the involved vessels, particularly the subclavian artery.
  • CT or MR angiogram is done to delineate the distribution and degree of arterial involvement.

"The diagnosis of Takayasu arteritis should be suspected strongly in a young woman who develops a decrease or absence of peripheral pulses, discrepancies in blood pressure, and arterial bruits. The diagnosis is confirmed by the characteristic pattern on arteriography, which includes irregular vessel walls, stenosis, post stenotic dilation, aneurysm formation, occlusion, and evidence of increased collateral circulation"

questions.text: Which of the following viral infection/infection is a strong risk factor for development of Polyarteritis Nodosa like vasculitis?
questions.solution:
• Chronic hepatitis B is strongest risk factor for development of PAN like vasculitis and circulating immune complexes are considered pathogenic

Polyarteritis Nodosa

  • multisystem, necrotizing vasculitis of small- and medium-sized muscular arteries in which involvement of the renal and visceral arteries is characteristic.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa does not involve pulmonary arteries, although bronchial vessels may be involved.
  • Involvement of venules is not seen in polyarteritis nodosa
  • Aneurysmal dilations up to 1 cm in size along the involved arteries are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.
  • The pathology in the kidney in polyarteritis nodosa is that of arteritis without glomerulonephritis.
  • The presence of a polyarteritis nodosa–like vasculitis in patients with hepatitis B together with the isolation of circulating immune complexes composed of hepatitis B antigen and immunoglobulin and the demonstration by immunofluorescence of hepatitis B antigen, IgM, and complement in the blood vessel walls strongly suggest the role of immunologic phenomena in the pathogenesis of this disease. A polyarteritis nodosa–like vasculitis has also been reported in patients with hepatitis C. Hairy cell leukemia can be associated with polyarteritis nodosa; the pathogenic mechanisms of this association are unclear.
  • A polyarteritis nodosa–like vasculitis has being described in con- junction with deficiency of adenosine deaminase type 2 (DADA2). Patients with DADA2 usually present in childhood with a variable pattern of clinical features and vascular pathology that is responsive to TNF inhibitors.

Clinical And Laboratory Manifestation:

  • Nonspecific signs and symptoms are the hallmarks of polyarteritis nodosa. Fever, weight loss, and malaise are present in over one-half of cases.

Diagnosis:

Biopsy of symptomatic organs such as nodular skin lesions, painful testes, and nerve/muscle provides the highest diagnostic yields. In the absence of easily accessible tissue for biopsy, the arteriographic demonstration of involved vessels, particularly in the form of aneurysms of small- and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature, is sufficient to make the diagnosis. Aneurysms of vessels are not pathognomonic of polyarteritis nodosa; furthermore, aneurysms need not always be present, and arteriographic findings may be limited to stenotic segments and obliteration of vessels.

questions.text: A 40 years old male presents with recurrent oral, genital ulcers. He has usually 4-5 episodes of painful oral/genital ulcers per year for last 2 years. Now he presents with painful acute red eyes for last 2 days and was diagnosed to have uveitis. Mild leucocytosis and thrombocytosis is present. Antinuclear antibody, ANA-profile is negative and pathergy test is positive. what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Behcet disease:

  • Behcet syndrome is a systemic vasculitis and presents with skin and mucosal lesions, uveitis, arthritis, major arterial and venous vessel disease, and gastrointestinal and neurologic manifestations.
  • It is relatively rare before the late teens and after age 50. Males and females are equally affected; however, males frequently have more severe disease and poorer outcomes.
  • Diagnosis: Behcet syndrome is diagnosed clinically. The most commonly used and best performing diagnostic criteria are the International Study Group (ISG) criteria (sensitivity ~95%, specificity ~96%); patients need to have recurrent oral ulcers plus two of the following four clinical manifestations: recurrent genital ulcers, skin lesions, eye lesions, or a positive pathergy test.
  • Vascular Manifestation can be seen in up-to 40% of the cases- superficial and deep venous thrombosis, inferior vena cava syndrome, pulmonary artery involvement, intracardiac thrombi and cerebral venous sinus thrombosis.
  • Laboratory Manifestation: Up to 50–60% of patients, depending on where they are from, can be positive for HLA B*51; however, it is not used as a diagnostic test because it is also found in up to 20% of the normal population.
  • Therapy
  • Oral topical glucocorticoid, oral colchicine, for oral ulcers
  • Apremilast-Phosphodiesterase 4 Inhibitor.
  • Uveitis-Glucocorticoids, Azathioprine, Infliximab
  • Gastrointestinal Involvement-Azathioprine, Infliximab

Causes of positive Pathergy Test:

  • Behcet disease
  • Pyoderma Gangrenosum
  • Sweet syndrome
  • Crohn's disease

questions.text: Saddle nose deformity and cauliflower ear is seen in which of the following inflammatory disease?
questions.solution:
Relapsing polychondritis:

  • Relapsing polychondritis is an uncommon disorder of unknown cause characterized by inflammation of cartilage predominantly affecting the ears, nose, and laryngotracheobronchial tree.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Auricular chondritis is the most frequent presenting manifestation of relapsing polychondritis. This typically involves the pinna of the ears, sparing the earlobes because they do not contain cartilage.
  • Inflammation of the internal auditory artery or its cochlear branch produces hearing loss, vertigo, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting. Vertigo is almost always accompanied by hearing loss.
  • Nasal cartilage involvement- nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and epistaxis, saddle nose deformity.
  • Arthralgia and Arthritis: in more than 50% patients
  • Eye manifestations occur in more than one-half of patients and include conjunctivitis, episcleritis, scleritis, iritis, uveitis, and keratitis.
  • Laryngotracheobronchial involvement occurs in ~50% of patients and is among the most serious manifestations of relapsing polychondritis. Symptoms include hoarseness, a nonproductive cough, and tenderness over the larynx and proximal trachea, tracheobronchomalacia.
  • Cardiac valvular regurgitation occurs in ~5–10% of patients and is due to progressive dilation of the valvular ring or to destruction of the valve cusps. Aortic regurgitation occurs in ~7% of patients.

Laboratory and Diagnostic Imaging

  • Antibodies to type II collagen are present in fewer than one-half of patients and are not specific. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), either cytoplasmic (c-ANCA) or perinuclear (p-ANCA), are found in some patients with active disease.
  • Diagnosis: includes biopsy evidence combined with three of the following: (1) recurrent chondritis of both auricles; (2) nonerosive inflammatory arthritis; (3) chondritis of nasal cartilage; (4) inflammation of ocular structures, including conjunctivitis, keratitis, scleritis/episcleritis, and/or uveitis; (5) chondritis of the laryngeal and/or tracheal cartilages; and (6) cochlear and/or vestibular damage manifested by neurosensory hearing loss, tinnitus, and/or vertigo.

Causes of saddle nose deformity:

  • Trauma (most common cause)
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis
  • Intranasal cocaine use
  • Malignancies
  • Syphilis
  • Crohn's disease
  • lepromatous leprosy

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Lofgren syndrome?
questions.solution:
Lofgren syndrome is a manifestation of sarcoidosis and consists of

  • Erythema Nodosum
  • Hilar Adenopathy
  • In some cases periarticular arthritis
  • Prognosis is good with >90% patients experiencing disease resolution within 2 years.
  • Associated with HLA-DRB1*03.

Sarcoidosis:

  • Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. The disease is often multisystemic and requires the presence of involvement in two or more organs for a specific diagnosis.

Clinical presentation:

  • Nonspecific constitutional symptoms include fatigue, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Fatigue is perhaps the most common constitutional symptom that affects these patients.
  • Lung is the most common affected organ-can be involved in up-to 95% individuals. Cough and dyspnoea are two most common symptoms. CT is the most sensitive imaging modality to detect pulmonary involvement.

Scadding staging of pulmonary involvement in Sarcoidosis

  • Stage 1: Hilar adenopathy
  • Stage 2: Adenopathy plus infiltrates
  • Stage 3: infiltrates alone
  • Stage 4: Fibrosis
  • The pulmonary Involvement in lung is an upper lobe process.

Differential diagnosis of upper lobe infiltrates:

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Silicosis
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Both restrictive and obstructive lung disease (in up-to 50% cases reflected by a reduced ratio of forced expiratory volume in 1 s to forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC)

Pulmonary artery hypertension is seen in 5% cases.

questions.text: Lupus pernio is a manifestation of which of the following systemic disease?
questions.solution:
Lupus pernio: chronic inflammatory skin lesion of sarcoidosis around the nose, eyes and cheeks is called as lupus pernio.

Skin involvement in sarcoidosis:

  • 2nd most common organ involved.
  • The classic cutaneous lesions include erythema nodosum, maculopapular lesions, hyper and hypopigmentation, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules. A specific complex of involvement of the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks is referred to as lupus pernio and is diagnostic for a chronic form of sarcoidosis.

Laboratory findings:

  • HRCT chest: interstitial lung disease and adenopathy
  • PET CT- to identify areas of granulomatous disease
  • Contrast MRI- GADOLINIUM enhancement indicates area of inflammation.
  • Elevated levels of ACE are reported in 60% of patients with acute disease and only 20% of patients with chronic disease.

Causes of significant elevation of serum ACE level:

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leprosy
  • Gaucher’s disease
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • disseminated granulomatous infections such as miliary tuberculosis. (Because the ACE level is determined by a biologic assay, the concurrent use of an ACE inhibitor such as lisinopril will lead to a very low ACE level)

Diagnosis:

Biopsy finding of noncaseating granuloma in presence of compatible clinical features. Biopsy from the lesions can be from skin, lung lesion (endobronchial ultrasound guided transbronchial lung biopsy)
